title: Trump Announces Temporary Control Of Venezuela Following Capture Of President Maduro | 10 News
description: The United States has captured long-serving Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro during an overnight operation on Saturday.  U.S. President Donald Trump said Maduro and his wife were “captured and flown out of the country” following what he described as a “large-scale strike” by U.S. forces.  Trump added that the United States would temporarily place Venezuela under American control, deploying U.S. forces “if necessary.”  Speaking to the media, Trump said, “So, I’d like to do it quickly, but it takes a period of time. You know, we’re rebuilding… we have to rebuild their whole infrastructure. The infrastructure is rotted. It’s actually very dangerous.”  Maduro and his wife arrived in New York on Saturday to face federal charges related to drug trafficking and alleged cooperation with gangs designated as terrorist organizations. Maduro has denied the accusations.  Maduro’s removal after more than 12 years in power has raised concerns about a potential power vacuum in Venezuela. title: Trump Signals Possible Deployment of US Ground Forces in Venezuela Following Maduro Arrest | 10 News
description: US President Donald Trump has said he is not afraid to “put boots on the ground” following the seizure of Venezuela into US control.  The comment comes after the overnight arrest of President Nicolás Maduro, with the U.S. prepared to take further military action if necessary.  Speaking to the media, Trump said, “We’re not afraid of boots on the ground if we have to. We had boots on the ground last night at a very high level, actually.”  He also confirmed that Secretary Marco Rubio has been in contact with Venezuela’s acting vice president and that the United States would oversee Venezuela “with a group,” that Rubio will manage. title: U.S. Launches Overnight Military Strike On Venezuela, Capturing President Nicolás Maduro | 10 News
description: An extraordinary and potentially explosive moment in global politics is unfolding right now.  The United States has launched a secret assault on Venezuela, capturing its president in a lightning raid just after 2am local time.  Elite Delta Force soldiers breached the Presidential Palace in Caracas, arresting Nicolás Maduro in what the White House is calling a decisive end to his rule. title: World Reacts To U.S. Strikes On Venezuela And Capture Of President Maduro | 10 News
description: From celebrations to condemnation, events in Venezuela have sent shockwaves far beyond the Americas.  Global leaders, caught unaware by the dramatic raid, are divided in their responses.   With the fallout yet to unfold, many including Anthony Albanese are calling for dialogue and diplomacy. title: 29-Year-Old Man Found In Boot Of Car After Alleged Kidnapping In Western Sydney | 10 News
description: A man has been found alive after being kidnapped, stabbed, and stuffed into the boot of a car in western Sydney.  He was discovered by chance when emergency crews were called to assist with another issue at a carpark next to a unit complex. title: Swiss Ski Bar Managers Under Criminal Investigation Over Deadly Fire | 10 News
description: Swiss prosecutors have launched a criminal investigation into the managers of a bar where a fire killed at least 40 people.  The French couple involved face charges of manslaughter by negligence, bodily harm by negligence, and arson by negligence. title: Sydney Storm Halts England’s Charge in Ashes Test At SCG | 10 News
description: Rain halted England’s progress as they looked to inflict more damage on Australia at the SCG today.  Joe Root and Harry Brook both scored half-centuries, helping England recover from a top-order collapse.  England were 3 for 211 before the weather intervened. title: Venezuelans Across The World Celebrate Capture Of Maduro | 10 News
description: Venezuelans in Barcelona and Mexico City have been celebrating the ousting of President Nicolas Maduro, following U.S. military intervention in the country.  U.S. President Donald Trump ordered the seizure of Maduro and confirmed that his nation would take control of Venezuela, with the ousted president currently being held in New York awaiting trial on drugs charges.  Venezuelan demonstrators in Mexico were seen marching with flags and signs reading 'freedom' with one woman in the Barcelona gathering calling for opposition leader Maria Corina Machado to be installed into power.  However, Trump has stated Machado lacks support and doesn't have the 'respect' to govern the South American nation. title: Protesters Rally Outside NYC Detention Centre Over Venezuelan President Maduro Capture | 10 News
description: Protesters have gathered outside the Metropolitan Detention Center in New York City, where Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro is being held after being seized from Caracas on Saturday.  The protests follow Trump’s announcement that the US would take control of the country.  The group chanted “Biggest threat in the world today, Donald Trump and the USA”, as some held signs reading “No US War on Venezuela”.  Maduro and first lady Cilia Flores are charged in the US with narco-terrorism conspiracy, cocaine importation conspiracy and weapons offences.  He is due to make his first federal court appearance in New York at noon local time on Monday. title: Hundreds March In Silence To Honour Victims Of Swiss Ski Resort Bar Fire | 10 News
description: Hundreds of people have marched in silence through the frosty streets of the Swiss ski resort of Crans-Montana to honour the victims of a fatal New Year’s Eve bar fire.  Following a church mass that spilled outdoors, the teary-eyed crowd slowly walked towards a shrine next to the "Le Constellation" bar for the 40 victims killed and around 119 people injured.  CEO of Crans-Montana Tourism Bruni Huggler said it was an important moment to get together and exchange support for each other, along with thanking the rescue team for their efforts.  Authorities have put the two people who ran the bar under investigation on suspicion of crimes including homicide by negligence.
